docs.lead_paragraph: After her third battle with cancer, Diana Dyer decided she needed something more than surgery and chemotherapy to keep the disease at bay. During treatment, she ate whatever she could tolerate to get the calories her body needed. But afterward, her goal was to use diet to minimize the risk of recurrence. She searched the scientific literature for guidance and developed a plan based, she recognized, on ''very little clinical science'' but on the best science available.

headline.main: For Survivors of Cancer, All Calories Are Not Equal

docs.abstract: Jane E Brody Personal Health column describes role diet can play in helping cancer patients through treatment and beyond; three-time cancer survivor Diane Dyer book Dietitian's Cancer Story provides readers with plan to eat healthy and hopefully stay cancer-free; American Cancer Society's publication Nutrition for the Person With Cancer describes importance of maintaining caloric intake during treatment and warns that some supplements could impede progress of therapy when taken in high doses; studies have not confirmed that macrobiotic diet reduces probabilty of getting cancer; drawing (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: As a June 27 front-page article about Schering-Plough indicates, neither I nor other members of the current senior management team can comment on the alleged events of the past. But we can say that at the new Schering-Plough, which we have been building for more than a year, we are committed to operating with integrity in every area of our work. We want to stress that the alleged inappropriate behaviors ascribed to people within the company were issues of the past. Since April 2003, the new management team has been working hard to transform the company into a high-performance competitor built on foundations of quality, compliance and business integrity. We are putting into effect robust compliance practices that range from specific controls for approvals of post-marketing clinical grants to integrated compliance training.
docs.abstract: Schering-Plough Corp senior vice president Brent Saunders letter responds to June 27 article; says new management team is transforming company into high-performance competitor built on foundations of quality, compliance and business integrity
